questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, although she has noticed that she can read a little better when holding the book below or above eye level. She also requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide and lisinopril. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. The results of a funduscopic examination are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic central serous retinopathy (CSR) manifests with progressive blurring of vision and central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing. Hypertension is a risk factor for CSR. Fundoscopy would show elevation of the macula and a halo-like reflex around it; yellow/pale spots on the macula are not consistent with this diagnosis. Finally, CSR most commonly manifests in men between the ages of 20 and 45.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The macula appears elevated (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

Circle: optic disc

B) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are neither soft nor hard exudates. Moreover, in the case of hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye

There are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.

These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

M: Macula

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, the region of retinal thickening at the macula (the dark red spot) would be larger than one disc diameter (due to macular edema). Also, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present in the remainder of the retina.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Neovascularization (example indicated by arrowhead) is evident at the temporal superior arcade as tortuous vessels originate from the normal retinal vasculature. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples indicated by blue overlay). Hard exudates appear as yellow lesions (examples indicated by green overlay). The retinal veins show periodic dilatations (venous beading; example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystoid macular edema can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions on fundoscopy. However, these spots would be hard exudates, unlike the drusen seen here, and they are typically arranged in a star-shaped configuration around the macula.

E) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

F) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

G) INCORRECT:

Doyne's honeycomb macular dystrophy can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and drusen around the macula on fundoscopy. However, the onset of symptoms typically occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Also, these drusen tend to be arranged radially, in contrast to the drusen in this patient, which are haphazardly arranged around the macula.

H) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.
questions.hint: The patient's blurring of central vision and Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia. The fundoscopy showing multiple yellow areas at the macula confirms the diagnosis. Since these spots do not obscure the retinal vessels, the pathology must be below the nerve fiber layer (i.e., either a hard exudate or a druse but not a cotton wool spot). The clustering of spots around the macula, the absence of sharp margins, and the absence of other retinal pathology indicate that these spots are soft drusen rather than hard exudates.

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy and the ophthalmologic findings are not consistent with retinoblastoma.

B) CORRECT:

This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. Higher arterial oxygen tension in a premature infant inhibits the production of VEGF, leading to apoptosis of endothelial cells and cessation of normal retinal vascular formation. Switching to room air results in relative hypoxia due to the lower oxygen concentration, increased metabolic demand of the growing retina, and poor vascular network, leading to the production of proangiogenic growth factors (e.g., VEGF) and uncontrolled neovascularization. The formation of new blood vessels can cause hemorrhages, form fibrovascular membranes, and ultimately lead to retinal detachment or blindness.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.

This finding is an example of plus disease, which indicates a risk for progression to ROP.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, as glucocorticoids play a vital role in promoting fetal lung maturity by stimulating the production of surfactant. However, glucocorticoid deficiency is not a risk factor for the development of ROP.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal diabetes causes chronic fetal hyperglycemia and can lead to a wide range of complications in the infant. This newborn's mother did not receive prenatal care, which means she was neither screened nor treated for diabetes during pregnancy. Maternal diabetes also increases the risk of prematurity, the single greatest risk factor for ROP. This infant does not have features consistent with chronic hyperglycemia, however, such as macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, cardiac anomalies, and respiratory distress. While this patient's ROP could be related to prematurity caused by maternal diabetes, another factor is much more likely responsible for his ROP.

E) INCORRECT:

Syphilis is one of several congenital infections (TORCH infections) that can cause ocular abnormalities in affected infants. Congenital syphilis can manifest with uveitis, keratitis, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts. However, this infant's fundoscopy findings are highly indicative of ROP, and, although infection may worsen the course of ROP, it is not a contributing factor to the development of this condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Head trauma as a result of rotational and shearing forces can cause shaken baby syndrome. This condition manifests with retinal and intracranial hemorrhages but does not contribute to the development of ROP.

G) INCORRECT:

Mothers receiving routine prenatal care are screened for chlamydia infection to eliminate the risk of chlamydial conjunctivitis in the newborn. This mother's lack of prenatal care puts the infant at risk of this disease, which often manifests 1–2 weeks after birth. However, ocular findings include mucopurulent or watery discharge, eyelid swelling, and chemosis. This disease does not affect the retina.
questions.hint: This infant's ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels and areas of nonvascularized peripheral retina, which are consistent with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of coughing, fatigue, night sweats, and 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. His cough is productive of blood-stained sputum. He works as an engineer and traveled to South Africa 2 months ago for a site inspection of a mine. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears ill with generalized wasting. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Respiratory examination shows dullness to percussion over the right lower lobe and crackles on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopy of the sputum shows acid-fast bacteria. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. At his follow-up visit 1 month later, the patient reports bilateral progressive, painless, blurred vision and an inability to distinguish between red and green. An adverse effect of which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects of rifampin include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic harmless orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, and tears). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrazinamide is used in the intensive phase of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects include hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., vomiting). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

C) CORRECT:

Ethambutol is used in conjunction with other agents to treat active tuberculosis during the initial phase of therapy. Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with decreased visual acuity, central and peripheral scotomas, and dyschromatopsia. Although its mechanism is unknown, the risk of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis increases with dose. Individuals receiving ethambutol should have ophthalmic evaluations performed at baseline and periodically during treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid (INH) is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Liver injury is a common adverse effect of INH, usually causing mildly elevated transaminases and, more rarely, fulminant hepatitis. Although INH can cause optic neuritis, it is a rare adverse effect that is more likely to develop with a different antibiotic.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine is an essential cofactor in the synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme. Because it competes with isoniazid (INH) in neurotransmitter synthesis, the drugs are commonly used together in antituberculosis therapy. Thus, pyridoxine should be used as an adjuvant in every regimen that includes INH. However, supplementation with pyridoxine does not cause optic neuritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of optic neuritis (blurred vision, dyschromatopsia) following the initiation of tuberculosis treatment. Irreversible blindness may develop with continued use of this drug.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He had no other symptoms and says he has never had a similar episode before. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/32 bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). The pupil is reactive and the cornea and anterior chamber are clear. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a few microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles, and bright yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery
Stenosis of the internal carotid artery
Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve
Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein
Stasis of blood in the atrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

Wet AMD can lead to subretinal hemorrhage, manifesting with acute monocular visual impairment. This patient does not have subretinal hemorrhage or any other signs of wet AMD (e.g., gray-green retinal discoloration, serous detachment of the retina) on fundoscopic examination and contrary to this patient's presentation, visual impairment after subretinal hemorrhage resolves slowly over several weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve (i.e., optic neuritis) typically manifests with monocular vision loss with a progressive onset over hours/days and a peak in impairment after 1–2 weeks, unlike this patient's presentation with amaurosis fugax. Patients with optic neuritis develop papilledema (in the case of papillitis) or have normal fundoscopic findings (in the case of retrobulbar neuritis).
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). His fundoscopic examination shows Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles), which are consistent with cholesterol crystal embolization. He also has signs of hypertensive retinopathy (e.g., microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles).

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the office for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?

A) INCORRECT:

Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy and the ophthalmologic findings are not consistent with retinoblastoma.

This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. The retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital syphilis can manifest with uveitis, keratitis, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts. questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h. ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the office because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, but improves when holding the book below or above eye level. She requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and diabetes mellitus. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. Fundoscopy shows soft drusen near the macula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are drusen, not exudates. Moreover, in hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye

There are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.

These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.

M: Macula

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Neovascularization (example indicated by arrowhead) is evident at the temporal superior arcade as tortuous vessels originate from the normal retinal vasculature. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples indicated by blue overlay). Hard exudates appear as yellow lesions (examples indicated by green overlay). The retinal veins show periodic dilatations (venous beading; example indicated by yellow overlay).

The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

C) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

D) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.
questions.hint: The patient's Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of left-sided neck swelling that has slowly progressed over the past 4 weeks. He has no history of serious illness. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows a nontender, mobile mass in the left submandibular region with overlying erythema. A biopsy of the mass shows caseating granulomas. Pharmacotherapy with azithromycin and ethambutol is initiated. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects related to ethambutol use?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat tuberculosis that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by preventing transcription (mRNA synthesis). Adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, tears). Ethambutol does not lead to orange discoloration of urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Many medications can cause acute kidney injury, including, in rare cases, ethambutol. However, this side effect would be more likely with streptomycin, an aminoglycoside that can be used to treat mycobacterial infections and works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis and damaging the bacterial cell wall. Additional adverse effects of streptomycin include ototoxicity, neuromuscular blockade (ataxia), and nephrotoxicity. Ethambutol is more likely to cause another side effect.

C) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness. Irreversible blindness may develop. The mechanism of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is not known but there is a dose-dependent correlation in risk of occurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Methemoglobinemia is a serious adverse effect of dapsone, an antibiotic that can be used for the treatment of Mycobacterium leprae infection (e.g. leprosy). Ethambutol is not known to cause methemoglobinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy is commonly observed with isoniazid, a prodrug activated by bacterial catalase-peroxidase that inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, a vital component of mycobacterial cell walls. Isoniazid is used mainly to treat tuberculosis. Adverse effects include vitamin B6 deficiency (a cofactor in the biosynthesis of important neurotransmitters), which can lead to peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral neuropathy is not a known adverse effect of ethambutol.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (unilateral, nontender lymphadenitis) and biopsy findings (caseating granulomas) suggest an infection with nontuberculous mycobacteria. Ethambutol works by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase, an enzyme involved in the polymerization and subsequent synthesis of mycobacterial cell walls.

questions.text: A 28-week preterm neonate on prolonged supplemental oxygen is noted to have abnormal retinal vessels. What is the most significant factor causing these findings?

choices.text: Excessively high partial pressure of oxygen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Retinopathy of prematurity is primarily caused by exposure to excessively high oxygen levels in preterm infants. The immature retinal vasculature is sensitive to hyperoxia, which downregulates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), leading to arrested angiogenesis and vaso-obliteration. As oxygen therapy is reduced, hypoxia in avascular retinal zones triggers a surge in VEGF, causing pathological neovascularization. This abnormal vessel growth can lead to leakage, fibrovascular proliferation, and potential retinal detachment. Careful oxygen titration and monitoring are crucial to prevent these complications in preterm neonates.

Key learning point: Hyperoxemia, or elevated oxygen levels, is the most significant causative factor for retinopathy of prematurity in premature infants.

B) INCORRECT:

While frequent red blood cell transfusions can contribute to oxidative stress, the primary cause of abnormal retinal vascular development in preterm infants is oxygen-related. High supplemental oxygen levels suppress growth factors, leading to vascular attenuation and subsequent pathological neovascularization.

C) INCORRECT:

Prolonged parenteral nutrition is associated with complications like cholestatic liver disease but does not directly affect retinal vascular development. The abnormal retinal vessels in preterm infants are primarily due to oxygen-induced injury, not nutritional factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hyperglycemia is associated with diabetic retinopathy, characterized by chronic microvascular damage from prolonged hyperglycemia. This mechanism is not applicable to the acute retinal changes in preterm infants, which are primarily due to oxygen-induced alterations in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) regulation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-week-old boy in your clinic for follow-up. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation by cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother had no prenatal care and has type 2 diabetes mellitus. On ophthalmologic examination, he has tortuous retinal vessels and well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his retinal findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. Higher arterial oxygen tension in a premature infant inhibits the production of VEGF, leading to apoptosis of endothelial cells and cessation of normal retinal vascular formation. Switching to room air results in relative hypoxia due to the lower oxygen concentration, increased metabolic demand of the growing retina, and poor vascular network, leading to the production of proangiogenic growth factors (e.g., VEGF) and uncontrolled neovascularization. The formation of new blood vessels can cause hemorrhages, form fibrovascular membranes, and ultimately lead to retinal detachment or blindness.

Key learning point: Retinopathy of prematurity is caused by oxygen toxicity in premature infants, leading to abnormal retinal neovascularization and risk of retinal detachment or blindness.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

The retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.

This finding is an example of plus disease, which indicates a risk for progression to ROP.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy and the ophthalmologic findings are not consistent with retinoblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Maternal diabetes causes chronic fetal hyperglycemia and can lead to a wide range of complications in the infant. This newborn's mother did not receive prenatal care, which means she was neither screened nor treated for diabetes during pregnancy. Maternal diabetes also increases the risk of prematurity, the single greatest risk factor for ROP. This infant does not have features consistent with chronic hyperglycemia, however, such as macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, cardiac anomalies, and respiratory distress. While this patient's ROP could be related to prematurity caused by maternal diabetes, another factor is much more likely responsible for his ROP.

D) INCORRECT:

Syphilis is one of several congenital infections (TORCH infections) that can cause ocular abnormalities in affected infants. Congenital syphilis can manifest with uveitis, keratitis, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts. However, this infant's fundoscopy findings are highly indicative of ROP, and, although infection may worsen the course of ROP, it is not a contributing factor to the development of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Head trauma as a result of rotational and shearing forces can cause shaken baby syndrome. This condition manifests with retinal and intracranial hemorrhages but does not contribute to the development of ROP.
questions.hint: This infant's ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels and areas of nonvascularized peripheral retina, which are consistent with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

questions.text: You are seeing a 72-year-old man in the emergency department 45 minutes after he experienced a sudden, painless, transient loss of vision in his right eye that lasted for 5 minutes. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 48-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h (0–10). ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

D) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

Key learning point: Transient monocular vision loss with Hollenhorst plaques is most often caused by retinal emboli from internal carotid artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of progressively worsening blurred vision in both eyes. She reports difficulty reading, which improves when she holds the book below or above eye level, and she needs a bright light to see objects more clearly. Her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually worsened. She has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. When viewing an Amsler grid, she notes that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. Fundoscopic examination reveals soft drusen near the macula. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

B) INCORRECT:

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.

Key learning point: Age-related macular degeneration is characterized by gradual central vision loss and drusen near the macula, making it the leading cause of vision impairment in older adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are drusen, not exudates. Moreover, in hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.
questions.hint: The patient's Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy brought to your clinic by his mother because of left-sided neck swelling that has gradually increased over the past 4 weeks. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 38.0°C. On examination, there is a nontender, mobile mass in the left submandibular region with overlying erythema. Biopsy of the mass reveals caseating granulomas. He is started on azithromycin and ethambutol. Which one of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur with ethambutol use in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B6 deficiency is commonly observed with isoniazid, which is used mainly to treat tuberculosis. Peripheral neuropathy due to ethambutol is very rare and typically associated with higher doses or prolonged use, particularly in individuals with renal impairment. A different adverse effect occurs more frequently.

B) INCORRECT:

Many medications can cause acute kidney injury, including, in rare cases, ethambutol. However, this side effect would be more likely with streptomycin, an aminoglycoside that can be used to treat mycobacterial infections. Additional adverse effects of streptomycin include ototoxicity, neuromuscular blockade (ataxia), and nephrotoxicity. Ethambutol is more likely to cause another side effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Methemoglobinemia is a serious adverse effect of dapsone, an antibiotic that can be used for the treatment of Mycobacterium leprae infection. Ethambutol is not known to cause methemoglobinemia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation (unilateral, nontender lymphadenitis) and biopsy findings (caseating granulomas) suggest an infection with nontuberculous mycobacteria. Treatment typically involves a macrolide (e.g., azithromycin, clarithromycin) plus ethambutol, with rifampin or rifabutin added for disseminated or more severe disease. Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness (particularly red–green dyschromatopsia). Irreversible blindness may develop. The mechanism of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is not known but there is a dose-dependent correlation in risk of occurrence.

Key learning point: Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis, which may present as blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat mycobacterial infections. Adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, tears). Ethambutol does not cause urine to become orange.
questions.hint: Chloroquine can also cause this particular adverse effect.
